text: the question of what's in the food we
eat has probably never been more
contentious is it good fat bad fat high
calories the high carbs in Europe
they're wrestling over whether horse
meat has been added to the food supply
but now fish that jumped into the game
in a big way
a nonprofit group called Oceana
purchased about 1,200 pieces of fish at
different retail outlets and found that
in 25 to 40% of the cases the fish were
not in fact at all what they purported
to be by far the worst offender on the
list was red snapper the group tested a
hundred and twenty purported red
snappers around the country and found
that in 28 cases they weren't red
snapper at all and in 17 they weren't
even in the snapper family the study
found significant variations among
cities Seattle in Boston both very much
seafood towns came out with some of the
lowest rates of deception the study had
bad news for residents of Southern
California in particular where half of
the samples were found to be mislabeled
places like Los Angeles in particular
that have a culture of sushi and
healthful eating we're hot beds of fish
that weren't what they seemed the
study's authors were careful not to take
it too far about what it could conclude
the sampling in Boston for example only
included grocery stores the researchers
said the best way to protect yourself
from mislabeled fish is through
relationships talk to your fishmonger
the guy behind the fish counter and ask
about where the fish came from and what
it is the more that they know that
customers care about what is being
labeled the more they're likely to pay
attention to the issue themselves I'm
Marcus Mabry for The New York Times
dr. Kimberly Warner is a senior
scientist at Oceana and joins me now to
talk about her group study good morning
dr. Warner good morning Marcus at what
point in the supply chain is this
mislabeling occurring
and why is it seemingly worse in cities
like Los Angeles than in say San
Francisco or Boston well that's an
interesting question we don't really
know we're along the supply chain the
fraud is occurring we only sampled at
the retail level but it could be
happening any place along this very
murky supply chain what we need is a
really good traceability system from
boat to plate that allows us to track
our fish and keep the same honest label
on it from the time it's caught to the
time it ends up on our dinner plate how
much of this is an enforcement issue
this is a are like Noah and their state
officials have been trying to crack down
on this of course budgets are tight and
we've seen over the years that the
enforcement efforts are simply not
enough since this has been a problem
that's been occurring for many many
years your organization has been at odds
in the past with the fishing industry
and we should say that we reach out to
the National Fisheries Institute the
trade organization and they did not
respond to our request for comment but
given some of the really disturbing data
points in your survey for instance a
claim that 94% of the tuna that was
tested here in New York City was not
actually what it purported to be what
assurances do we have about the
methodology of your study well we're
very confident in our results we used
forensic DNA technology barcoding DNA
barcoding for most of our samples
they're all analyzed genetically and so
these tell you not only what your fish
isn't but also what it is what is being
served in its place so some of the
substitutions were really disturbing
that we found for example in New York
City we found that a lot of the high
mercury fish were being called safer
fish like red snapper and halibut in the
study Oceana says the best way for
consumers to protect themselves and our
bureau chief and in Seattle mention this
is through a personal relationship with
your fishmonger
but what about the millions of consumers
who actually you know get their fish at
the local supermarket and don't have a
relationship with their fishmonger how
can they protect themselves
well they could look at the price of
that's being offered on a seafood item
if it's too good to be true sometimes it
is and they can speak up with their
elected officials when there are good
traceability legislation going through
Congress they can say we want this to
happen we're willing to support honestly
labeled seafood that's legally caught
and you know if we don't speak up I am
afraid this is gonna keep on happening
well thanks for joining us thank you
very much for having me Marcus that's
all for now
I'm Marcus Mabry for The New York Times
